In one of your most recent plays you take on the issue that we're calling the school to prison pipeline where children are essentially criminalized and on that very young ages and um it's something that it's become a huge problem in in the United states how do you take a topic like that
And bring it to the stage and keep audiences involved in such a heavy topic well

A I call it a subsidy inside of Detroit um and so because of that I I just have a vast knowledge about teaching I've spent so much time and so many schools across New York city and all of you know the many public high school and elementary schools

To teaching because of that it's a public school teachers and private schools teaching I've been in both

To teaching because of that as a public school teachers and private schools teaching I've been in bowl

Her relationship to the public school system her son who goes to a private school and had relationships that private school system and we're looking at
Basically within the two forms of education how institutions can fail children an educator
Both in the public school maybe infrastructure ally but in private schools culturally and both of those things are harmful to young people and can lead them to not having enough space for the total humanity and their emotional ... young especially young black and brown boys and our nation and so that was important for me to try to explore

Specifically have within the creative fields

To being more positions of power and where they are making those decisions that so I think we need to see a shift and that sort of the work that I Do as an artist

Of diverse backgrounds into the house to have an experience together that's what makes theater special and that's what my work has to be the catalyst for

Leave their communities to come over to see something at your house if you are not ever willing to go to them
